newsitem.title: USA: Carter to head election observers in Liberia.
newsitem.headline: Carter to head election observers in Liberia.

text.p: Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter said on Tuesday he will travel to Liberia this month as leader of an international delegation set up to observe the West African nation's July 19 elections.
The 40-member team will arrive in Liberia by July 14 and be on hand to observe voting throughout the country.

"As impartial observers, we are neutral with regard to the outcome, but partial to the democratic process," Carter said in a statement released by the Carter Centre, an Atlanta-based organisation devoted to humanitarian aid and democratic reform.
"The presence of the Carter Centre (team) and other international observers will help to ensure that the Liberian people can freely express their choice in a secret ballot."
The Carter team was expected to work closely with officials from the United Nations, the European Union and a group called Friends of Liberia.
Carter has visited the war-torn region four times to meet with interim governments and faction leaders. On a fifth visit last month he helped assess preparations for the voting.
Since 1989 the Carter Centre has observed elections in a dozen countries including Panama, Nicaragua, Haiti, the United States, Mexico and China.
